block.p: Amish School Survivors Struggle After Killings Seven members of Leroy Zook's family were in the one-room Amish schoolhouse in Nickel Mines, Pa., on Monday morning when Charles C. Roberts IV rapped on the door armed with chains, clamps and guns. All the Zooks, including Mr. Zook's wife and two daughters, got out unharmed, but not unshaken.
PAGE A20

Another Dow Record The Dow Jones industrial average, shrugging off a weak report on factory orders, had its second consecutive record close, climbing above 11,800. Nasdaq shares rose more than 2 percent, their highest level in five months.
BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C15
Problems for Hedge Funds Hedge funds have hit a rough patch. Yet investors continue to pour in money and hope that the next fund with a problem will not be one of theirs.
BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1

U.S. Warning for North Korea The Bush administration warned North Korea not to conduct a nuclear test and significantly toughened its position, saying the United States ''is not going to live with'' a nuclear-armed North Korea.
PAGE A8
A Second-Generation Nobel Winner Dr. Roger D. Kornberg, left, won this year's Nobel Prize in Chemistry. His father, Dr. Arthur Kornberg, shared the Nobel in medicine in 1959.
PAGE A20
New Nuclear Debate in Iran A forgotten letter from 1988 suggests that Iran has sought nuclear weapons for decades, undermining its contention that its nuclear fuel is only for peaceful purposes.
PAGE A14

R. W. Apple Jr., Times Globe-Trotter, Dies at 71 In more than 40 years as a correspondent and editor at The New York Times, R. W. Apple Jr. wrote from more than 100 countries about war and revolution, politics and government, food and drink, and the revenge of living well.
Mr. Apple, who was known as Johnny, enjoyed a career like no other in the modern era of The Times.
PAGE B8

Discord at Brooklyn Museum A sweeping reorganization at the Brooklyn Museum is causing dissension within the ranks, playing a part in the recent resignations of three veteran curators and two board members.
